children.subject: Hi! https://ugrad.seas.upenn.edu/student-handbook/programs-options/submatriculation-engineering/ I understand the unique circumstances at Cal, such as huge amount of students.. But I think it's possible to do something to remedy the needs for an accelerated 1 year grad program here.
I don't see any reference to any sort of automatic admission for an accelerated/5th year's masters program or a 3.7 GPA threshold in the linked webpage.

Hi! I am sorry for the confusion and it appears that there is no such info on the webpage, I got the information from one of my friends in Upenn CS who is preparing for this program. I think regardless of how other schools are doing, it maybe a somewhat meaningful suggestion for relaxing the criteria for entering the 5th year program at Cal. i.e., student can perhaps choose from using a good rec. letter with more relaxed GPA requirement, or a stricter GPA requirement with relaxed requirement for rec. letter, etc?

I can clearly see the benefit of this to some students but:

1) The biggest problem by far is that the university probably doesn't have the resources for this. I doubt professors have the bandwidth to take on the number of students this would admit. 

2) While the program is listed as industry-oriented, the research project you do is an integral part of it. Having a high GPA is neither necessary nor sufficient for doing quality research, which is another reason why blindly admitting students above a certain GPA probably isn't a good idea

3) I don't see how you can equitably offer students the option of picking between a good GPA or strong letter of rec when applying to the program. There's a reason these applications are intended to be holistic

4) As has been noted earlier in the post, this suggestion was meant to hold some weight because UPenn has a similar one, but it doesn't seem that that's the case. Plus Upenn has far fewer CS/EECS majors so it's not really a fair comparison anyway

The main thing is that for the Masters at UPenn research isn’t a required portion, so it’s pretty much just enrollment in a couple of graduate courses. As such they can enroll everyone who wants to join. Here though a professor needs to work with you on your research, so we can’t do the same thing.

That's very true. But why must our program require a research, if it's already meant to be industry-oriented? I think a significant amount of people (me included) wish to go directly to industry, and if I go to the 5th year program, my goal is to advance my industry career, but we need to allocate time in our undergrad to do a research whose whole purpose is to be admitted to an industry-oriented program?
This I completely agree with, but I don't think we're going to switch over anytime soon. I believe our peers like CMU have the same research requirements.

@Anon poet we already have the MEng program that's fully industry-oriented, so why not apply to that? I don't see why the 5th year master's program needs to be altered if we already have a non research-based industry oriented master's program at Berkeley

https://ugrad.seas.upenn.edu/student-handbook/programs-options/submatriculation-engineering/
https://www.college.upenn.edu/submatriculation
I got confirmation from my Upenn friend that it is true that they only need to submit this form without letter of rec and and their submatriculate master degree also doesn't require research thesis.

I understand that we already have MEng program, but that is open to the public to apply and therefore very competitive :))

Ah sorry, since Fall 2018 they need 1 letter of rec. letter, but it seems they don't require research to get a good letter of rec. as ours. But I fully understand that here at Cal we have much more students than theirs, so I do fully understand the necessity of our policy..It seems there is just too much demand for too little resources

I actually heard that MEng isn't that hard to get into if you already did your undergrad in eecs/cs here, so consider checking it out if you don't think you have sufficient research experience for the 5th year master's?

Do you have any references for this claim? It would be very difficult for Berkeley to enact such a policy since the 5th years masters here requires individual professors to commit to sponsoring individual students for the duration of the program.

history.content:
Hi! It seems that University of Pennsylvania (which is also a very very good university) offers a 5th year MS for all undergrad CS majors (without requiring GRE, research / recommendation letter) with the requirement of a 3.7 GPA, and all that students need to do is to submit a form. I am wondering if Berkeley could provide similar opportunities? Many of us are focusing on industry career, and we may not have adequate time to devote on acquiring a research, and since our industry-oriented 5th year program is already focusing on industry rather than research, I am wondering if the requirement for a research / recommendation letter can be waived, provided that we have adequate GPA to demonstrate enough academic ability for continuing a career in Grad program here at Berkeley?
Thanks!!
history.subject: Unconditional MS program for one year after UnderGrad career?
